page.title: Qiu Shi Science and Technology Prize

revision.comment: Robot - Moving category Science and engineering awards to [[:Category:Science and technology awards]] per [[WP:CFD|CFD]] at [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion/Log/2016 July 18]].
revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{orphan|date=August 2012}} {{notability|date=July 2012}} {{unreferenced|date=July 2012}} }}
'''Qiu Shi Prizes''' are awarded on an annual basis in recognition of advances in science and technology. The Qiu Shi Science and Technology Foundation was established by Mr. [[Cha Chi Ming]] 查濟民 (1914-2007) in 1994 in Hong Kong, with the intention of promoting science and technology research in China, and to encourage and reward successful Chinese scientists and scholars. Prizes are awarded each year Prize categories include Physics, Chemistry, Physiology or Medicine, Mathematics or Information Technology.
'''Qiu Shi''' (Chinese: 求是； pinyin Qiu2 shi4; pronounced ch-OO/sh-ER) means “seeking truth”. The Qiu Shi Foundation was named after the famous Qiu Shi Academy (求是书院) in Hangzhou, which was subsequently renamed [[Zhejiang University]] 浙江大学. Qiu Shi Science and Technology Foundation is not related to the Qiushi Journal, the political theory periodical.
== Founder/Foundation == Cha Chi-ming, GBM, JP, was born in 1914, in Haining County, Jiaxing, Zhejiang province. He studied textile technology and graduated from Zhejiang University in 1931. Cha was best known for his industrial prowess, building a multinational textile conglomerate. He was the chairman of CDW International Limited, The Mingly Corporation Limited and Hong Kong Resort International Limited.
== The Qiu Shi Advisory Board == Members:
[[Chen Ning Yang]] (a Nobel laureate in physics), [[Zhou Guangzhao]] (physician, and honorary chairman of China Association for Science and Technology), [[Yuan T. Lee]] (a Nobel laureate in chemistry), [[Yuet Wai Kan]] (genetic researcher), [[David Ho (scientist)|David Ho]] (physician and innovator of the "cocktail" therapy for HIV), [[Andrew Yao]] (computer scientist and the first Asian A.M. [[Turing Award]] recipient).
== Prize types == Alumni
== References == * {{cite web|title=Qiu Shi Science and Technology Foundation|url=http://www.qiushi.org/index.php?m=content&c=index&a=lists&catid=26}}
[[Category:Science and technology awards]] [[Category:Science and technology in China]]

revision.comment: Added a discovery
revision.text:
[[File:GlenrockCoalLineOnYuelarbahTrack.JPG|thumb|An example of an abandoned railway line]] '''Railway archaeology''' is the study and enjoyment of relics from past eras of rail transportation (including railways and tramways of all gauges and sizes). The aim of railway archaeology is to learn about the history and see images of the previous appearance of a defunct rail system that became redundant or abandoned and to enjoy searching out these remains and exploring them.
Railway archaeology comes under the general ambit of the study of the industrial past and therefore is a sub-set of [[Industrial archaeology]].
==Societies undertaking railway archaeology== The Railway Archaeological Society, a UK-based group that seems to be defunct.
Light Railway Research Society of Australia is an Australian-based society that was formed in 1961 to promote interest in special-purpose railways. Much of its members' work would fall into the category of Railway archaeology.
==Discoveries== * '''London Bridge Station''' Archaeologists have discovered hundreds of artifacts at an excavation site under the London Bridge Station. Excavation pits were dug 6 meters deep revealing many artifacts from Roman times, timber piles that were recorded as to be from 59 AD to 83 AD that was used for buildings during the first London Bridge, and Medieval floors. The Archaeologists continue excavating the site for more artifacts around the 16th and 18th centuries.<ref>https://www.networkrail.co.uk/archaeological-finds-at-london-bridge-station/</ref> * '''Victorian Era''' Archaeologists in London have discovered a railway infrastructure near the London tube station created by Isambard Kingdom Brunel, an engineer that is well known for his invention approximately 200 years ago called the Broad-Gauge Great Western Steam Railway. The area has evidence of seven foot-wide broad gauge train tracks and buildings from the 1850s. At the moment, Archaeologists are further researching the site with laser scanning technology for more artifacts of the Victorian-era railway.<ref>http://www.culture24.org.uk/history-and-heritage/archaeology/art500045-victorian-railway-infrastructure-discovered-by-archaeologists-near-london-tube-station</ref> They are also using a series of 3D models of the architecture of the 1850s buildings in order to identify paths of the railway. * '''Derbyshire''' In May 2013, a group of archaeologists have discovered what is believed as the oldest railway tunnel at Derbyshire in England (United Kingdom.) The tunnel lies on the route of the Butterley Gangroad, a horse-operated railway built by 1793 to link the Cromford Canal with the limestone quarries at Crich. The line closed in 1933 after being open for over 100 years and the tunnel was sealed up 50 years later in the 1980s. Trevor Griffin, who is project managing the work for the Derbyshire Archaeological Society, said he thought the tunnel could be older than the one regarded as the world's first - which is also in Derbyshire. He said: "The tunnel that was currently generally considered to be the world's oldest was on the Peak Forest Tramway and was built in 1795." The two-year project began in January. The society worked with Wessex Archaeology to reopen the tunnel and made a three-dimensional computer model of the interior using laser scanning. Written evidence suggested the railway was operating by 1793 and Mr Griffin says they were able to prove the line must have run through the tunnel. The Butterley Gangroad, which was engineered by Benjamin Outram, was modernised in the 1840s and turned into a narrow gauge railway. When the work is completed, the tunnel will be sealed up for further preservation.
==See also== * [[Railpage Australia]] * [[Omoto locomotive dump]]
==References== {{reflist}} ;Sources * Nock, O.S 1981 ''Railway Archaeology'', Book Club Associates/Patrick Stephens Ltd. * <nowiki>http://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-derbyshire-22342239</nowiki>
[[Category:Industrial archaeology| ]]

revision.text:
'''Railway costing''' is the calculation of the variable and fixed costs of rail movements. Variable costs are those that increase or decrease with changes in the traffic volumes or service levels and include fuel, maintenance and train crew costs, for example. Fixed costs are normally associated with items such as head office, interest charges and other overhead. Unit costs can then be calculated based on the expenses of the railway divided into standard categories.
==Types of cost== In order to assist in its deliberations regarding rate and service complaints, the [[Canadian Transportation Agency]] has identified various types of costs. These costs include:
*the maintenance and operation of way and structures, such as track and roadway, signals, communication, and fuel stations[https://web.archive.org/web/20060925022533/http://www.cta-otc.gc.ca/rail-ferro/finance/rail_cost_e.html] *the maintenance and operation of equipment, such as locomotives, freight cars, intermodal equipment, and work equipment[https://web.archive.org/web/20060925022533/http://www.cta-otc.gc.ca/rail-ferro/finance/rail_cost_e.html] *railway operations, such as train and yard operations, train control, and intermodal[https://web.archive.org/web/20060925022533/http://www.cta-otc.gc.ca/rail-ferro/finance/rail_cost_e.html] *general costs, such as general administration, employee benefits, taxes, insurance, purchasing and material stores[https://web.archive.org/web/20060925022533/http://www.cta-otc.gc.ca/rail-ferro/finance/rail_cost_e.html] *cost of capital[https://web.archive.org/web/20060925022533/http://www.cta-otc.gc.ca/rail-ferro/finance/rail_cost_e.html] *depreciation[https://web.archive.org/web/20060925022533/http://www.cta-otc.gc.ca/rail-ferro/finance/rail_cost_e.html]
==Methodology== The methodology used in railway costing breaks down the costs of rail traffic to their unit value and from there determines their relationship to traffic handled and service provided. Therefore, as traffic and services change, the effect of these changes can be estimated from the unit values previously determined. The costing model methodology allows for variable costs to increase as traffic increases, whereas the fixed costs will remain constant, regardless of the overall level of traffic.
==Mathematical models== Railway costing is typically performed using [[mathematical model]]s. Using unit costs from current operating data and current accounting and operating information, it is possible to develop costing information for the railway. This costing information may be used to estimate the operating cost of a new line and to determine whether it is economically viable. Alternatively, the model could be used to estimate the cost effects of changing speed limits along a route. The savings that can be achieved with a railway costing model are endless. For example, by knowing the costs of doing business, a railway can appropriately determine the tariffs to be charged.
In addition, railway costing models typically handle passenger and freight traffic, making them applicable in more situations, including mixed traffic situations.
some commercial variations of railway costing models have been implemented, including the OSCAR railway costing model developed by [[CPCS Transcom Limited]]. CPCS is an international infrastructure development firm and has successfully used this model in dozens of its projects worldwide.
The Cartage railway costing model was developed by Vectorail, a global supplier of railway costing solutions with more than forty years of experience in the field.
== External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060925022533/http://www.cta-otc.gc.ca/rail-ferro/finance/rail_cost_e.html Canadian Transportation Agency]
[[Category:Management accounting]] [[Category:Information systems]] [[Category:Rail technologies]]

[[Caltech]] |doctoral_advisor = |academic_advisors = |doctoral_students = |notable_students = |known_for = Radar Interferometry |author_abbrev_bot = |author_abbrev_zoo = |influences = |influenced = |awards = |religion = |signature = |footnotes = }} '''Richard M. "Dick" Goldstein''' (born April 1927){{citation needed|date=April 2012}} is an American radar astronomer and planetary scientist, who has been called "The Father of Radar Interferometry." ==Biography== Richard Goldstein was born in [[Indianapolis, Indiana]]. He studied Electrical Engineering at [[Purdue]]. After working at his family furniture store for eleven years, he followed his brother (astronomer [[Samuel J. Goldstein, Jr.]]) to [[California]] and NASA's [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]]. He is married to Ruth Goldstein (née Lowenstam). As a graduate student at [[Caltech]] in 1961, Goldstein used the antenna at the [[Goldstone Tracking Station]] to obtain the first realtime radar echos from the planet [[Venus]].{{cite thesis |type=Ph.D. |first=Richard M |last=Goldstein |title=Radar Exploration of Venus |publisher=Caltech |date=1962}} By 1963, Goldstein and co-author had measured the period and retrograde rotation of [[Venus]].{{cite journal|last=Goldstein, RM|author2=Carpenter, RL|journal=Science|date=1963|title=Rotation of Venus - Period Estimated from RADAR Measurements|volume=139|issue=355|doi=10.1126/science.139.3558.910|url=http://www.sciencemag.org/content/139/3558/910.abstract|pmid=17743054|bibcode = 1963Sci...139..910G|first1=R. M.|pages=910–1 }} Using his same techniques, he confirmed Soviet experiments that acquired radar echoes from [[Mercury (planet)|Mercury]]{{cite journal |last=Carpenter |first=Roland |last2=Goldstein |first2=R. M. |title=Radar Observations of Mercury |journal=Science |volume=142 |date=1963 |pages=381–2|bibcode = 1963Sci...142..381C |doi = 10.1126/science.142.3590.381 |issue=3590 |pmid=17799479 }} and he was first to obtain echos from [[Mars]] in 1963.{{cite journal |last=Goldstein |first=R. M. |last2=Gillmore |first2=Willard F. |title=Radar Observations of Mars |journal=Science |volume=141 |date=1963 |pages=1171–1172|bibcode = 1963Sci...141.1171G |doi = 10.1126/science.141.3586.1171-a |issue=3586 |pmid=17751790 }} In 1968, Goldstein was the first to obtain a radar echo from an asteroid, when he measured the radar cross section of [[Icarus]].{{cite journal |last=Goldstein |first=R. M. |title=Radar Observations of Icarus |journal=Science |volume=162 |date=1968 |pages=903–904 |doi=10.1126/science.162.3856.903 |pmid=17769079 |issue=3856|bibcode = 1968Sci...162..903G }} Later he also measured the size and rotational period of the nucleus of a comet.{{cite journal|author=Goldstein, RM|author2=Jurgens, RF|author3=Sekanina, Z|title=A RADAR Study of Comet IRAS-Araki-Alcock 1983D|journal=Astronomical Journal|date=1984|volume=89|issue=11|doi=10.1086/113683|bibcode=1984AJ.....89.1745G|pages=1745}} In 1964, Goldstein had analyzed the spectrum of radar echos from Venus to obtain the first images of features on the surface of that planet. Later, using range-Doppler and radar interferometric techniques, he was able to create some of the first maps of the planet.{{cite journal |last=Goldstein |first=R. M. |last2=Rumsey |first2=Howard C. |title=A Radar Image of Venus |journal=Icarus |volume=17 |issue=3 |date=1972 |pages=699–703 |doi=10.1016/0019-1035(72)90034-6 |bibcode=1972Icar...17..699G}} Goldstein was also first to get echos from [[Ganymede (moon)|Ganymede]]{{cite journal |last=Goldstein |first=R. M. |last2=Morris |first2=G. A. |title=Ganymede: Observations by Radar |journal=Science |volume=188 |date=1975 |pages=1211–1212 |doi=10.1126/science.188.4194.1211 |issue=4194|bibcode = 1975Sci...188.1211G |pmid=17818164 }} and later other moons of [[Jupiter]].{{cite journal|display-authors=8|last=Ostro |last2=Campbel |last3=Simpson |last4=Hudson |last5=Chandler |last6=Rosema |last7=Shapiro |last8=Standish |last9=Winkler |last10=Yeomans |last11=Velez |last12=Goldstein |first1=S. J.|first2=D. B.|first3=R. A.|first4=R. S.|first5=J. F.|first6=K. D.|first7=I. I.|first8=E. M.|first9=R.|first10=D. K.|first11=R.|first12=R. M.|title=Europa, Ganymede, and Callisto - New RADAR Results from Arecibo and Goldstone|journal=Journal of Geophysical Research: Planets|date=1992|volume=97|issue=E11|doi=10.1029/92JE01992|bibcode=1992JGR....9718227O|pages=18227}} He also detected Saturn’s rings using radar.{{cite journal |last=Goldstein |first=R. M. |last2=Morris |first2=G. A. |title=Radar Observations of the rings of Saturn |journal=Icarus |volume=20 |issue=3 |date=1973 |pages= 260|doi=10.1016/0019-1035(73)90002-X |bibcode=1973Icar...20..260G}} Goldstein began work in the mid 1980s on topographical mapping techniques using [[synthetic aperture radar]]. Initially using two antennas (and later a single antenna with a repeated track), he was able to use the phase interferometry to improve over stereoscopic optical mapping techniques.{{cite journal |last=Zebker |first=H. A. |last2=Goldstein |first2=R. M. |title=Topographic Mapping From Interferometric Synthetic Aperture Radar Observations |journal=Journal of Geophysical Research |volume=91 |date=1986 |pages=4993–4999 |doi=10.1029/JB091iB05p04993 |bibcode=1986JGR....91.4993Z}} Goldstein then developed his revolutionary "crabgrass growing" algorithm for phase unwrapping, which resolves ambiguities in phase data and isolates local noise and errors that would otherwise cause global errors.{{cite journal |last=Goldstein |first=R. M. |last2=Zebker |first2=H. A. |last3=Werner |first3=C. L. |title=Satellite radar interferometry - Two-dimensional phase unwrapping |journal=Radio Science |volume=23 |issue=4 |date=1988 |pages=713–720 |doi=10.1029/RS023i004p00713 |bibcode=1988RaSc...23..713G}}{{cite journal|last=Rosen |last2=Hensley |last3=Joughin |last4=Li |last5=Madsen |last6=Rodriguez |last7=Goldstein |first1=P.A.|first2=S.|first3=I.R.|first4=F.K.|first5=S.N.|first6=E.|first7=R.M.|title=Synthetic aperture radar interferometry - Invited paper|journal=Proceedings of the IEEE|date=2000|volume=88|issue=3|doi=10.1109/5.838084|pages=333}} This algorithm simplified the creation of accurate elevation maps,{{cite journal|last=Zebker|last2=Goldstein |first1=Howard A.|first2=Richard M.|title=Topographic Mapping from Interferometric Synthetic Aperture RADAR Observations|journal=Journal of Geophysical Research: Solid Earth|date=1986|volume=91|issue=B5|doi=10.1029/JB091iB05p04993|bibcode=1986JGR....91.4993Z|pages=4993}} and made possible many new applications for radar interferometry, including satellite detection{{cite journal|last=Li|last2=Goldstein|first1=F.K.|first2=R.M.|title=Studies of Multibaseline Spaceborne Interferometric Synthetic Aperture RADARS|journal=IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing|date=1990|volume=28|issue=1|doi=10.1109/36.45749|bibcode = 1990ITGRS..28...88L|pages=88 }} and quantification of small changes such as land subsidence,{{cite journal|last=Fielding|last2=Blom|last3=Goldstein |first1=Eric J.|first2=Ronald G.|first3=Richard M.|title=Rapid subsidence over oil fields measured by SAR interferometry|journal=Geophysical Research Letters|date=1998|volume=25|issue=17|doi=10.1029/98GL52260|bibcode=1998GeoRL..25.3215F|pages=3215}} ice flow motion,{{cite journal |last=Goldstein|last2=Engelhardt|last3=Kamb|last4=Froclich |first1=R. M.|first2=H.|first3=B.|first4=R. M. |title=Satellite RADAR Interferometry for Monitoring Ice-sheet Motion - Application to an Antarctic Ice Stream|journal=Science|date=1993|volume=262|issue=5139|doi=10.1126/science.262.5139.1525|bibcode = 1993Sci...262.1525G|pages=1525–30|pmid=17829380 }} ocean currents,{{cite journal|last=Goldstein|last2=Zebker |first1=R. M.|first2=H.A.|title=Interferometric RADAR Measurement of Ocean Surface Currents|journal=Nature|date=1987|volume=328|issue=6132|doi=10.1038/328707a0|pages=707}} and geological fault shifts.{{cite journal|last=Zebker|last2=Rosen|last3=Goldstein|last4=Gabriel|last5=Werner |first1=Howard A.|first2=Paul A.|first3=Richard M.|first4=Andrew|first5=Charles L. |title=On the Derivation of Coseismic Displacement-fields using Differential RADAR Interferometry - The Landers Earthquake|journal=Journal of Geophysical Research: Solid Earth|date=1994|volume=99|issue=B10|doi=10.1029/94JB01179|bibcode=1994JGR....9919617Z|pages=19617}} Subsequent work includes algorithms for mitigating thermal noise in the phase data, yielding dramatic improvements in the quality of measurement and phase data.{{cite journal |last=Goldstein |first=R. M. |last2=Werner |first2=C. L.|title=Radar interferogram filtering for geophysical applications |journal=Geophysical Research Letters |volume=25 |issue=21 |date=1998 |pages=4035–4038 |doi=10.1029/1998GL900033 |bibcode=1998GeoRL..25.4035G}} In the 1990s, Goldstein also worked on applying radar techniques for detecting orbital debris. Previous radar approaches were able to detect orbiting objects as small as 5mm. By using short wavelength pulses and a separate antenna to detect echos, Goldstein was able to improve the detection of objects to less than 2mm at a 600 km altitude.{{cite book |author=Committee on Space Debris, National Research Council |title=Orbital debris: a technical assessment |publisher=National Academies Press |date=1995 |isbn=978-0309051255}} In the process, he discovered that the Earth has rings of debris (some apparently left over from the [[West Ford Project]]). He has continued to refine the technique, extending the capabilities to detect 3mm objects as far away as 3200 km.{{cite journal |last=Goldstein |first=R. M. |last2=Goldstein |first2=S. J. |last3=Kessler |first3=D. J.|title=Radar observations of space debris |journal=Planetary and Space Science |volume=46 |issue=8 |date=1998 |pages=1007–1013 |doi=10.1016/S0032-0633(98)00026-9 |bibcode=1998P&SS...46.1007G}} Goldstein is a regular participant and frequent award-winner in the annual JPL Invention Challenge.{{cite web |url=http://www.jpl.nasa.gov/events/inventionchallenge/index.cfm |title=JPL Annual Invention Challenge |accessdate=11 March 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120309073034/http://www.jpl.nasa.gov/events/inventionchallenge/index.cfm |archivedate=9 March 2012 |df= }} ==Honors== NASA Honors Award, Exceptional Engineering Achievement Medal, 2000 Asteroid 5393 named [[5393 Goldstein]]{{cite book|last=Schmadel|first=Lutz D.|title=Dictionary of Minor Planet Names, Volume 1|date=2003|publisher=Springer Verlag|isbn=9783540002383|author2=International Astronomical Union|page=461}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{cite book |last1=Butrica |first1=Andrew J. |title=To See the Unseen, A History of Planetary Radar Astronomy |url=https://history.nasa.gov/SP-4218/contents.htm |date=1996 |publisher=NASA History Office |isbn=978-0160485787}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Goldstein, Richard}} [[Category:American astronomers]] [[Category:1927 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Indianapolis]] [[Category:Synthetic aperture radar]]

revision.text:
A '''Satellite Emergency Notification Device''' or '''SEND''' is a portable emergency notification and locating device which uses commercial satellite systems rather than the [[Cospas|COSPAS-SARSAT]] satellite system. An example of this device is [[SPOT Satellite Messenger|SPOT]].
The devices use an internal [[Global Positioning System|GPS]] chip to gather location information. When the SEND is triggered, this information is sent via commercial satellite to a commercial monitoring agency whose role is to pass the information to an appropriate responding agency. The responding agency contacted depends, in part, on the location. Examples of responding agencies would be military Search and Rescue, Coast Guard, local police, voluntary Search and Rescue.
Typical users/purchasers of these devices are participants in activities such as hiking, mountain biking, climbing, boating and flying. They are also useful for those who work in remote areas (loggers, foresters, geologists, fisheries and wildlife staff).
Additional features are increasingly being offered: sending preprogrammed messages, breadcrumb tracking via [[Google Earth]]. Some newer devices offer two-way communication via satellite, for example [[DeLorme]]'s inReach Communicator and the Yellowbrick 3 Messenger/Tracker.<ref>[http://www.yellowbrick-tracking.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/08/YB3_datasheet_en.pdf] Yellowbrick two-way messenger datasheet</ref>
The considerations when buying them, is ensuring that the International Emergency Response Coordination Centre (IERCC) which receives a distress call maintains an accurate and up-to-date database of response agencies to contact and can quickly determine which is appropriate to the situation/location. The commercial, IERCC is GEOS, used by both SPOT and DeLorme SENDs.
The [[USCG|US Coast Guard]]'s National Search and Rescue Committee (NSARC) set up a working group which includes representation from other US agencies, international organizations and device manufacturers to discuss how these "technologies can be properly reviewed and integrated with the SAR response system in the United States"<ref>[http://www.uscg.mil/hq/cg5/cg534/nsarc/NSARC_SEND_minutes_Dec09.pdf] NSARC minutes from December 2009</ref> and to aid the [[RTCM|Radio Technical Commission for Maritime Services (RTCM)]] in "development of a minimum operating and performance specification for such devices".<ref>[http://www.icao.int/icaoimojwg/meetings/jwg16/docs/JWGSAR16_wp09.pdf] Emerging technologies in commercially available alerting devices from [[International Civil Aviation Organization|ICAO]]/[[International Maritime Organization|IMO]] JOINT WORKING GROUP, October 2009</ref> The RTCM working group SC has completed and approved a standard for Emergency Satellite Notification Systems, which was published in August 2011.<ref>[http://www.navcen.uscg.gov/pdf/gmdss/taskForce/TFSR_67.pdf] NATIONAL GMDSS IMPLEMENTATION TASK FORCE</ref>
BriarTek was granted a US Patent<ref>[http://www.equipped.org/US7991380_Global_Bidirectional_Beacon_Briartek. pdf] US Patent 7,991,380 B2</ref> on August 2, 2011 for a "Global Birectional Locator Beacon and Emergency Communications System", which covers SENDs with Receive / Transmit capabilities such as the DeLorme inReach unit.
== inReach == inReach, like SPOT, does not use the 406 MHz signal nor the system of satellites. Instead, it depends on the Iridium satellite system. Unlike SPOT, inReach is a two way system capable of receiving confirmation that the message was received. Like SPOT, the message is transmitted to the private GEOS International Emergency Response Center who then notifies the appropriate SAR authorities.
inReach also provides tracking capability and two way SMS text messages.
== SPOT == SPOT does not use the 406 MHz signal nor the system of satellites. Instead, it depends on the [[GlobalStar]] satellite system. It has richer features (for instance, can send many non-emergency signals) - but it does not work in as many places as 406 MHz PLBs - for instance under dense forest canopy or steep canyons.<ref>[http://www.equipped.org/SPOT_ORSummer2007.htm SPOT Satellite Messenger FIRST LOOK - EQUIPPED TO SURVIVE (tm)<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> When a user presses the "911" button on a SPOT device an emergency message containing the unit's identification and GPS location is transmitted to the GEOS International Emergency Response Center who then notifies the appropriate emergency agency for the region after first calling the user to ensure the transmission is not accidental.<ref>[https://www.findmespot.com/en/index.php?cid=104 SPOT Emergency Response]</ref><ref>[http://www.geosalliance.com/sar/ GEOS Search And Rescue]</ref>
SPOT additionally has the ability to provide non-emergency web based tracking information. This allows family or friends at home to track the holder's progress. The tracking operates by sending a tracking signal to the [[GlobalStar]] network every 10 minutes. This feature can additionally be useful to provide location of an individual even if the individual is unable to activate the emergency '911' button.<ref>[https://www.findmespot.com/en/index.php?cid=104 How SPOT works]</ref>
Typical costs are $169 plus a $99/year service fee for basic services or $150/yr for basic services and tracking services, as compared to around $250 for a 406-MHz PLB with no service fee.
== Yellowbrick == Yellowbrick, like SPOT, does not use the 406 MHz signal nor the system of satellites. Instead, it depends on the Iridium satellite system. Unlike SPOT, Yellowbrick is a two way system capable of receiving confirmation that the message was received and exchange two-way messages via short emails and SMS. Alert messages are transmitted to destinations specified by the owner.<ref>[http://www.yellowbrick-tracking.com/ Yellowbrick Website] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140722152215/http://www.yellowbrick-tracking.com/|date=2014-07-22}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Emergency locator beacon]] * [[Emergency position-indicating radiobeacon station]], which covers PLB, ELT, EPIRB
==References== <references/>
==External links== * [http://tracknsend.com/2012/09/patent-bombshell/ BriarTek claims patent on SENDs] * [http://blog.delorme.com/2011/06/03/delorme-inreach-two-way-satellite-communication/ Announcement By DeLorme of the inReach Communicator] * [http://www.yellowbrick-tracking.com/?p=1327 Announcement by Yellowbrick of their tracking and communication device] * [http://www.equipped.org/blog/?p=331 SEND standard approved by RTCM] * [http://www.geosalliance.com/ GEOS – CERC service for SENDs such as the SPOT and inReach]
{{Telecommunications}}

revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=March 2008}} In the [[microelectronics]] industry a '''semiconductor fabrication plant''' (commonly called a '''fab'''; sometimes '''foundry''') is a factory where devices such as [[integrated circuits]] are manufactured.
A business that operates a semiconductor fab for the purpose of fabricating the designs of other companies, such as [[fabless semiconductor company|fabless semiconductor companies]], is known as a foundry. If a foundry does not also produce its own designs, it is known as a [[pure-play semiconductor foundry]].
Fabs require many expensive devices to function. Estimates put the cost of building a new fab over one [[1000000000 (number)|billion]] [[United States dollars|U.S. dollars]] with values as high as $3–4 billion not being uncommon. [[TSMC]] invested $9.3 billion in its ''Fab15'' 300 mm [[Wafer (electronics)|wafer]] manufacturing facility in Taiwan.<ref>[http://www.tsmc.com/tsmcdotcom/PRListingNewsAction.do?action=detail&language=E&newsid=5041TSMC Begins Construction on Gigafab In Central Taiwan] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120129181137/http://www.tsmc.com/tsmcdotcom/PRListingNewsAction.do?action=detail&language=E&newsid=5041TSMC |date=2012-01-29 }}, issued by TSMC, 16 July 2010</ref> The same company estimations suggest that their future fab might cost $20 billion. <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theinquirer.net/inquirer/news/3018890/tsmc-says-3nm-plant-could-cost-it-more-than-usd20bn|title=TSMC says 3nm plant could cost it more than $20bn - TheINQUIRER|author=|date=|website=theinquirer.net|accessdate=26 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171012043608/https://www.theinquirer.net/inquirer/news/3018890/tsmc-says-3nm-plant-could-cost-it-more-than-usd20bn|archivedate=12 October 2017|df=}}</ref>
The central part of a fab is the [[clean room]], an area where the environment is controlled to eliminate all dust, since even a single speck can ruin a microcircuit, which has features much smaller than dust. The clean room must also be damped against vibration and kept within narrow bands of temperature and humidity. Controlling temperature and humidity is critical for minimizing static electricity.
The clean room contains the [[stepper]]s for [[photolithography]], [[Etching (microfabrication)|etching]], cleaning, [[doping (semiconductors)|doping]] and [[Wafer dicing|dicing]] machines. All these devices are extremely precise and thus extremely expensive. Prices for most common pieces of equipment for the processing of 300 mm wafers range from $700,000 to upwards of $4,000,000 each with a few pieces of equipment reaching as high as $130,000,000 each (e.g. steppers). A typical fab will have several hundred equipment items.
==History== Typically an advance in chip-making technology requires a completely new fab to be built. In the past, the equipment to outfit a fab was not very expensive and there were a huge number of smaller fabs producing chips in small quantities. However, the cost of the most up-to-date equipment has since grown to the point where a new fab can cost several billion dollars.
Another side effect of the cost has been the challenge to make use of older fabs. For many companies these older fabs are useful for producing designs for unique markets, such as [[embedded processor]]s, [[flash memory]], and [[microcontroller]]s. However, for companies with more limited product lines, it's often best to either rent out the fab, or close it entirely. This is due to the tendency of the cost of upgrading an existing fab to produce devices requiring newer technology to exceed the cost of a completely new fab.
There has been a trend to produce ever larger [[wafer (electronics)|wafer]]s, so each process step is being performed on more and more chips at once. The goal is to spread production costs (chemicals, fab time) over a larger number of saleable chips. It is impossible (or at least impracticable) to retrofit machinery to handle larger wafers. This is not to say that foundries using smaller wafers are necessarily obsolete; older foundries can be cheaper to operate, have higher yields for simple chips and still be productive.
The current, as of 2014, state-of-the-art for wafer size is 300 mm (12 in). The industry is aiming to move to the 450 mm wafer size by 2018.<ref>[http://www.itrs.net/Links/2011ITRS/2011Chapters/2011ExecSum.pdf 2011 Report] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120710084135/http://www.itrs.net/Links/2011ITRS/2011Chapters/2011ExecSum.pdf |date=2012-07-10 }} - [[International Technology Roadmap for Semiconductors]]</ref> As of March 2014, [[Intel]] expects 450 mm deployment by 2020.<ref name="intel450mm">{{cite web | url = http://blog.timesunion.com/business/intel-says-450mm-will-deploy-later-in-decade/59430/ | title = Intel says 450 mm will deploy later in decade | date = 2014-03-18 | accessdate = 2014-05-31 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140513010946/http://blog.timesunion.com/business/intel-says-450mm-will-deploy-later-in-decade/59430/ | archivedate = 2014-05-13 | df = }}</ref> Additionally, there is a large push to completely automate the production of semiconductor chips from beginning to end. This is often referred to as the "[[lights out (manufacturing)|lights-out fab]]" concept.
The International Sematech Manufacturing Initiative (ISMI), an extension of the US consortium [[SEMATECH]], is sponsoring the "300 mm Prime" initiative. An important goal of this initiative is to enable fabs to produce greater quantities of smaller chips as a response to shorter lifecycles seen in consumer electronics. The logic is that such a fab can produce smaller lots more easily and can efficiently switch its production to supply chips for a variety of new electronic devices. Another important goal is to reduce the waiting time between processing steps.<ref>Chip Makers Watch Their Waste</ref><ref>ISMI Press Release</ref>
==See also==
*[[Foundry model]] for the business aspects of foundries and fabless companies *[[Klaiber's law]] *[[List of semiconductor fabrication plants]] *[[Rock's law]] *[[Semiconductor consolidation]] *[[Semiconductor device fabrication]] for the process of manufacturing devices
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
==References== * ''Handbook of Semiconductor Manufacturing Technology, Second Edition'' by Robert Doering and Yoshio Nishi (Hardcover – Jul 9, 2007) * ''Semiconductor Manufacturing Technology'' by Michael Quirk and Julian Serda (paperback – Nov 19, 2000) * ''Fundamentals of Semiconductor Manufacturing and Process Control'' by Gary S. May and Costas J. Spanos (hardcover – May 22, 2006) * ''The Essential Guide to Semiconductors'' (Essential Guide Series) by Jim Turley (paperback – Dec 29, 2002) * ''Semiconductor Manufacturing Handbook'' (McGraw–Hill Handbooks) by Hwaiyu Geng (hardcover – April 27, 2005)
== Further reading == * "Chip Makers Watch Their Waste", ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'', July 19, 2007, p.B3
== External links == *[https://web.archive.org/web/20071017102115/http://ismi.sematech.org/corporate/news/releases/20070719.htm ISMI Press Release]

{{Multiple issues| {{Unreferenced|date=June 2018}} {{Cleanup|section|date=December 2009}} }} {{redirect|SMS-C|the weather satellite|GOES-1}}
A '''Short Message Service Center''' ('''SMSC''') is a network element in the [[mobile phone|mobile]] telephone network. Its purpose is to store, forward, convert and deliver [[Short Message Service]] (SMS) messages.
The full designation of an SMSC according to 3GPP is ''Short Message Service - Service Center (SMS-SC).''
Basic Trajectories of SMS are # From mobile to another mobile - referred to as MO-MT (Mobile Originated - Mobile Terminated) # From mobile to a content provider (also known as Large Account / ESME) - referred to as MO-AT (Mobile Originated - Application Terminated) # From application to a mobile - referred to as AO-MT (Application Originated - Mobile Terminated)
==Operation== The tasks of an SMSC can be described as # Reception of text messages (SMS) from wireless network users # Storage of text messages # Forwarding of text messages # Delivery of text messages (SMS) to wireless network users # Maintenance of unique time stamps in text messages
When a user ''sends'' a text message (SMS message) to another user, the message gets stored in the SMSC (short message service centre), which delivers it to the destination user when they are available. This is a [[Store-and-forward switching center|store and forward]] option.
An SMS centre (SMSC) is responsible for handling the SMS operations of a wireless network.
# When an SMS message is sent from a mobile phone, it will first reach an SMS centre. # The SMS centre then forwards the SMS message towards the destination. # The main duty of an SMSC is to route SMS messages and regulate the process. If the recipient is unavailable (for example, when the mobile phone is switched off), the SMSC will store the SMS message. # It will forward the SMS message when the recipient is available and the message's expiry period is not exceeded.
SMSCs can be used to interface with other applications, for example a spreadsheet can interface with the SMSC allowing messages to be sent SMS from an [[Microsoft Excel|Excel spreadsheet]], or to send an SMS from Excel. Inbound messages to a long number or short code can also be passed through the SMSC allowing m2m communications or Telematics.
===Validity period of an SMS message=== An SMS message is stored temporarily in the SMS center if the recipient mobile phone is unavailable. It is possible on most mobile handsets to specify an expiry period after which the SMS message will be deleted from the SMS center. Once deleted, the SMS message will no longer be available for dispatch to the recipient mobile phone (even if it comes on line). The validity period should be regarded by the handset user as a request, as the SMSC itself can be configured to ignore or otherwise handle message delivery schedules.
===Message status reports=== The SMS sender needs to set a flag in the SMS message to notify the SMS centre that they want the status report about the delivery of this SMS message. This is usually done by changing a Setting on the mobile handset.
==See also== * [[Short Message Service technical realisation (GSM)]] * [[IS-41]] * [[SMPP]] * [[Universal Computer Protocol|UCP/EMI]] * [[CIMD]]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Short Message Service Centre}} [[Category:Mobile technology]] [[Category:Telecommunications infrastructure]] [[Category:Text messaging]]

A '''simulated pregnancy''' is a deliberate attempt to create the impression of [[pregnancy]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/12/09/fake-pregnancy-bellies-china_n_1139157.html |title=Fake Pregnancy Bellies Popular In China, Online Sales Increasing, Report Says |publisher=Huffingtonpost.com |date= 2011-12-09|accessdate=2012-06-06 |first=Ileana |last=Llorens}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/china/2012-05/29/content_15407761.htm |title=Fake silicon bellies are pregnant with possibility |Society |publisher=chinadaily.com.cn |date= |accessdate=2012-06-06}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=F_474 |url=http://english.peopledaily.com.cn/90882/7666537.html |title=Fake pregnant belly becomes hot seller on the Internet - People's Daily Online |publisher=English.peopledaily.com.cn |date=2011-12-06 |accessdate=2012-06-06}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/10/05/mommy-tummy-pregnancy-simulator-men_n_996945.html |title='Mommy Tummy' Pregnancy Simulator Lets Men Experience What It Feels Like To Carry A Baby (Video) |publisher=Huffingtonpost.com |date= 2011-10-05|accessdate=2012-06-06 |first=Ileana |last=Llorens}}</ref>
It should not be confused with [[false pregnancy]], where a person mistakenly believes that they are pregnant.
== Techniques == People who wish to ''look'' pregnant, generally for social, sexual, entertainment, or psychological purposes, have the option of body suits and the like to wear under their clothes. It can be done by using [[pillows]] or pads, or light-weighing, small balls with a round shape to simulate a pregnant abdomen. A common practice is to place a form replicating a belly (rolled up clothes, deflated ball, etc.) under a skin colored, tight bodysuit. This creates a realistic color and shape.
== Reasons == The reasons for a person to desire a simulated pregnancy vary greatly from one individual to another. It could be an intellectual curiosity, a cosmetic effect or social experiment, an erotic or sexual experience, or part of a larger psychological issue. A simulated pregnancy may in some cases be a manifestation of [[factitious disorder]].
==See also== * [[Couvade syndrome]]
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Prosthetics]] [[Category:Human pregnancy]]
{{psych-stub}} {{human-repro-stub}}

{{multiple issues| {{lead too short|date=March 2012}} {{unreferenced|date=March 2012}} }} [[File:Sony Sports Watchman - Austin Calhoon Photograph.jpg|thumb|Sony Sports Watchman]] [[File:Sony MEGA Watchman - Austin Calhoon Photograph.jpg|thumb|Sony MEGA Watchman]] [[File:Sony Watchman TV FD-10A Austin Calhoon Photograph.jpg|thumb|Sony FD-10 Pocket Watchman]] The '''Sony Watchman''' is a line of portable [[Handheld television|pocket televisions]] trademarked and produced by [[Sony]]. The line was introduced in 1982 and discontinued in 2000.
==FD-210== The initial model was introduced in 1982 as the FD-210, which had a grayscale five [[centimeter]] display. The device weighed around 650 [[gram]]s, with a measurement of 87 x 198 x 33 [[millimeter]]s. The device was sold in Japan with a price of 54,800 [[yen]]. Roughly two years later, in 1984, the device was introduced to [[Europe]] and [[North America]].
==Later releases== [[File:Sony watchman models.jpg|thumb|Various models of Sony Watchmen]] Sony manufactured more than 65 models of the Watchman before its discontinuation in 2000. Upon the release of further models after the FD-210, the display size increased, and new features were introduced. The FD-3, introduced in 1987, had a built-in digital clock. The FD-30, introduced in 1984 had a built-in AM/FM Stereo radio. The FD-40/42/44/45 were among the largest Watchmen, utilizing a 4" CRT display. The FD-40 introduced a single composite A/V input. The FD-45, introduced in 1986, was water-resistant. In 1988/1989, the FDL 330S color Watchman TV/Monitor with LCD display was introduced. In 1990, the FDL-310, a Watchman with a color [[Liquid crystal display|LCD display]] was introduced. The FD-280/285, made from 1990 to 1994, was the last Watchman to use a black and white CRT display. One of the last Watchmen was the FDL-22 introduced in 1998, which featured an ergonomic body which made it easier to hold, and introduced Sony's ''Straptenna'', where the wrist strap served as the antenna.
==Legacy== Due to the switch of television broadcasts to digital, most models of the Sony Watchman have lost their usefulness, because they now require to be connected to a digital converter box.
==Marketing and media== A model of the Sony Watchman is seen multiple times in the film [[Rain Man]].
==External links== {{Commonscat|Sony Watchman}} * [http://uv201.com/TV_Pages/panasonic_tr001.htm Reverse Time Page] * [http://www.guenthoer.de/e-history.htm The Short History of Pocket TV] * Vintage Micro Television https://web.archive.org/web/20131212201648/http://www.visions4.net/journal/time-line/
{{Sony Corp}}

{{Infobox company | name = Tuniu Corporation | native_name = 途牛旅游网 | native_name_lang = zh | romanized_name = | logo =File:Tuniu_Corporation_Logo.png | type = Public | traded_as = [[NASDAQ]]: TOUR [http://www.nasdaq.com/markets/ipos/company/tuniu-corp-931587-75081] | founded = 2006 | hq_location = [[Nanjing]], [[China]] | key_people = Donald Dunde Yu ([[CEO]] and co-founder) Alex Haifeng Yan (COO and co-founder) | industry = [[Tourism]] | revenue = USD$1.6 billion | revenue_year = 2015 | num_employees = 8000 | website = {{url|www.tuniu.com}} }}
'''Tuniu Corporation''' ({{zh|s=途牛旅游网}}) is a Chinese [[online travel agency]]. Products and services include packaged tours, accommodation reservation, airline and railway ticketing, car rentals, and corporate travel. The company listed on the [[NASDAQ|Nasdaq Stock Exchange]] on May 9, 2014. The company [[headquarters]] are located in [[Nanjing]] with offices in [[Shanghai]] and [[Beijing]].
== History == Founded in 2006 in Nanjing by current [[Chief executive officer|CEO]] Donald Dunde Yu and current [[Chief operating officer|COO]] Alex Haifeng Yan, the company was fully incorporated on June 1, 2008.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/finance/stocks/companyProfile?symbol=TOUR.O|title=TUNIU Company Profile|last=|first=|date=|website=Reuters|publisher=|language=en-US|access-date=2017-01-05}}</ref>
On May 9, 2014, Tuniu was listed on the Nasdaq Stock Exchange under TOUR, co-managed by [[Morgan Stanley|Morgan Stanley & Co]], [[Credit Suisse|Credit Suisse Securities LLC]] and China Renaissance Securities. Tuniu raised $72 million in its [[initial public offering]], pricing 8 million shares at $9 per share. CEO Donald Dunde Yu rang the opening bell at the [[NASDAQ MarketSite|Nasdaq MarketSite]] in [[Times Square]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://usa.chinadaily.com.cn/2014-05/10/content_17497703.htm|title=Tuniu’s IPO on Nasdaq raises $72m{{!}}|last=|first=|date=|website=usa.chinadaily.com.cn|publisher=China Daily|access-date=2017-01-05}}</ref>
In April 2015, Tuniu was the subject of a boycott by seventeen Chinese travel agencies over a pricing dispute.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.techinasia.com/major-chinese-travel-agents-launch-boycott-tuniu|title=Major Chinese travel agents launch boycott of Tuniu|last=Custer|first=C.|date=Apr 23, 2015|website=www.techinasia.com|publisher=Tech in Asia|language=en-US|access-date=2017-01-05}}</ref> The issue was settled a few days later following an investigation by the [[China National Tourism Administration]], with partner relations returning to normal.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://english.cri.cn/12394/2015/04/25/4081s875979.htm|title=Tourism Authority to Investigate the Boycott of Tuniu.com|website=english.cri.cn|access-date=2017-01-05}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.chinatravelnews.com/article/91540|title=Tuniu boycott ends as tour operators come back in the fold under CNTA oversight|last=|first=|date=Apr 27, 2016|website=www.chinatravelnews.com|publisher=ChinaTravelNews|access-date=2017-01-05}}</ref> Tuniu's share price fell 4.7% following news of the dispute.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://blogs.barrons.com/asiastocks/2015/04/23/tuniu-tumbles-on-supplier-boycott-oversold-says-morgan-stanley/|title=Tuniu Tumbles On Supplier Boycott: Oversold, Says Morgan Stanley|last=Ren|first=Shuli|newspaper=Barrons|access-date=2017-01-05}}</ref>
On August 23, 2016, Tuniu’s Board of Directors authorized a [[Share repurchase|share repurchase program]] to repurchase up to $150 million worth of shares.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://asia.tools.euroland.com/tools/Pressreleases/GetPressRelease/?ID=3222643&lang=en-GB&companycode=cn-tour&v=cn-tour_press|title=Tuniu Announces US$150 Million Share Repurchase Program|last=|first=|date=Aug 23, 2016|website=asia.tools.euroland.com|publisher=|access-date=2017-01-05}}</ref> Tuniu’s share price had fallen below opening price.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-04-04/china-s-travel-site-tuniu-hurt-by-economic-woes-stronger-rivals|title=China's Travel Site Tuniu Hurt by Economic Woes, Stronger Rivals|date=2016-04-04|newspaper=Bloomberg.com|access-date=2017-01-05}}</ref>
== Investments and acquisitions == On July 1, 2014, [[Ctrip]] CEO [[James Liang|James Jianzhang Liang]] was appointed to Tuniu’s Board of Directors.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://asia.tools.euroland.com/tools/Pressreleases/GetPressRelease/?ID=3210345&lang=en-GB&companycode=cn-tour&v=cn-tour_press|title=Tuniu Appoints New Director|website=asia.tools.euroland.com|access-date=2017-01-05}}</ref> On December 10, 2014, Tuniu and Ctrip signed a strategic collaboration agreement to share travel resources.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://asia.tools.euroland.com/tools/Pressreleases/GetPressRelease/?ID=3210320&lang=en-GB&companycode=cn-tour&v=cn-tour_press|title=Tuniu and Ctrip Sign Strategic Collaboration Agreement|website=asia.tools.euroland.com|access-date=2017-01-05}}</ref>
On December 15, 2014, Tuniu announced $148 million investment in aggregate from a group that included the investment arms of [[Hony Capital]], [[JD.com]], Ctrip Investment Holding Ltd, and the personal holding companies of Tuniu’s CEO and COO. Ctrip acquired $15 million Tuniu shares during their IPO, and currently owns over 3% of Tuniu’s outstanding shares.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://asia.tools.euroland.com/tools/Pressreleases/GetPressRelease/?ID=3210319&lang=en-GB&companycode=cn-tour&v=cn-tour_press|title=Tuniu Announces US$148 Million Investment in Aggregate from a Group of Investors|website=asia.tools.euroland.com|access-date=2017-01-05}}</ref>
In May, 2015, Tuniu announced the investment of $500 million from a group of investors led by JD.com. JD.com became the largest shareholder in Tuniu with 27.5% stake.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.tnooz.com/article/tuniu.com-500m-dollars-investment-JD.com-ctrip/|title=China's Tuniu secures $500 million led by JD.com|newspaper=Tnooz|language=en-US|access-date=2017-01-05}}</ref>
On March 9, 2015, Tuniu announced the acquisition of majority stakes in two Chinese travel agencies, [[Hangzhou]]-based Zhejiang Zhongshan International Services and [[Tianjin]]-based China Classical Holiday.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://asia.tools.euroland.com/tools/Pressreleases/GetPressRelease/?ID=3210313&lang=en-GB&companycode=cn-tour&v=cn-tour_press|title=Tuniu Announces the Acquisitions of Two Travel Agencies|website=asia.tools.euroland.com|access-date=2017-01-05}}</ref>
On January 21, 2016, Tuniu announced the completion of a US$500 million investment from [[HNA Group|HNA Tourism Group]]. Transaction purchase price was US$5.50 per Class A ordinary share. HNA Tourism Group bought 24.1% share of Tuniu.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://asia.tools.euroland.com/tools/Pressreleases/GetPressRelease/?ID=3209095&lang=en-GB&companycode=cn-tour&v=cn-tour_press|title=Tuniu Announces the Completion of US$500 Million Investment from HNA Tourism|website=asia.tools.euroland.com|access-date=2017-01-05}}</ref>
== Brand ambassadors == In July 2016, Tuniu announced the signing of [[Taiwan|Taiwanese]] pop stars [[Jay Chou]] and [[Jimmy Lin]] as its celebrity brand ambassadors.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.chinatechnews.com/2016/07/18/23776-who-will-challenge-ctrips-internet-travel-supremacy-in-china|title=Who Will Challenge Ctrip’s Internet Travel Supremacy In China?|website=ChinaTechNews.com|access-date=2017-01-05}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://roll.sohu.com/20140311/n396414135.shtml|title=途牛网管理层：携手林志颖 打造广告界“去哪儿”-搜狐滚动|last=|first=|date=|website=roll.sohu.com|publisher=|language=zh|access-date=2017-01-05}}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == *{{Official website|http://www.tuniu.com}} *[http://ir.tuniu.com/ Investor relations website] *Stock pages: [http://www.nasdaq.com/markets/ipos/company/tuniu-corp-931587-75081 NASDAQ] | [https://www.bloomberg.com/quote/TOUR:US Bloomberg] | [http://finance.yahoo.com/quote/TOUR?ltr=1 Yahoo] | [https://www.reuters.com/finance/stocks/overview?symbol=TOUR.O Reuters]

[[File:Navit sdl close view.png|thumb|[[Navit]] turn-by-turn navigation]] '''Turn-by-turn Navigation''' is a feature of some [[GPS navigation device]]s where directions for a selected route are continually presented to the user in the form of spoken or visual instructions.<ref>{{cite book |title=Handbook of transport systems and traffic control |last=Button |first=Kenneth J. |author2=David A. Hensher |year=2001 |publisher=[[Emerald Group Publishing]] |location= |isbn=978-0-08-043595-4 |page=497 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=COMbsJ8QqzYC&pg=PA497&dq=turn-by-turn+navigation&hl=en&ei=FXbTTOrzC4SwuAOAl4TWBA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10&ved=0CFsQ6AEwCTgo#v=onepage&q=turn-by-turn%20navigation&f=false |accessdate=}}</ref> The system keeps the user up-to-date about the best route to the destination, and is often updated according to changing factors such as traffic and road conditions.<ref>{{cite book |title=Global information infrastructure: the birth, vision, and architecture |last=Targowski |first=Andrzej |authorlink= |year=1998 |publisher=IGI Global |location=Hershey, PA |isbn=978-1-878289-32-2 |page=264 |pages= |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HyvMYDWj9ocC&pg=PA264&dq=turn-by-turn+navigation&hl=en&ei=wXXTTIPfPIuWvAOEqpz4BA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=9&ved=0CFAQ6AEwCDge#v=onepage&q=turn-by-turn%20navigation&f=false |accessdate=}}</ref> Turn-by-turn systems typically use an electronic voice to inform the user whether to turn left or right, the street name, and how much distance to the turn. <ref>{{cite book |title=Human computer interaction |last=Jacko |first=Julie A. |year=2009 |publisher=[[Springer Science+Business Media]] |location= |isbn=978-3-642-02579-2 |page=141 |pages= |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Rz6NJA5ZatsC&pg=PA141&dq=turn-by-turn+navigation&hl=en&ei=OnTTTLXeIIXsuAP_u7GKBQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0CD8Q6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=turn-by-turn%20navigation&f=false |accessdate=}}</ref>
Mathematically, turn by turn navigation is based on the [[shortest path problem]] within [[graph theory]], which examines how to identify the path that best meets some criteria (shortest, cheapest, fastest, etc.) between two points in a large network.
[[File:TomTomOne.jpg|thumb|A TomTom device]]
==Devices and services== Major mapping services that offer turn-by-turn navigation, grouped by map data provider:<ref name="comp" /> *[[Nokia]].<ref name="OReilly_1">{{cite web |url=http://radar.oreilly.com/2009/10/google-shrinks-another-market.html |title=Google Shrinks Another Market With Free Turn-By-Turn Navigation |author=Brady Forrest |date=14 October 2009 |publisher=[[O'Reilly Media]] |accessdate=4 November 2010}}</ref> Devices that use [[Here (company)|HERE Technologies]] map data:<ref name="comp">See [[comparison of web map services]]</ref> **[[Garmin]] car navigators<ref name="OReilly_1"/> **[[Nokia]] smartphones running either [[Symbian]], [[Maemo]], or [[Windows Phone]] (HERE Technologies Maps software is included as standard on [[Nokia Lumia]] Windows Phones) *[[Google Maps]] and [[Yahoo! Maps]].<ref name="OReilly_1"/> Devices that use [[Tele Atlas]] map data:<ref name="comp" /> **[[TomTom]] car navigators<ref name="OReilly_1"/> **[[Android (operating system)|Android]] smartphones on-line through [[Google Maps]] (included as standard)<ref name="OReilly_1"/> **[[Apple iPhone]] on-line through [[Google Maps]]{{Citation needed|date=December 2011}} * [[OpenStreetMap]]. Offline-capable applications that use volunteer-contributed data: ** [https://kartatech.com Karta GPS], a navigation app for [[iOS]] and [[Android (operating system)|Android]] ** [[openstreetmap:Magic_Earth|Magic Earth]] by [https://www.generalmagic.com General Magic], a free navigation app for [[iOS]] and [[Android (operating system)|Android]] **[[MAPS.ME]], a free and open-source app for [[iOS]], [[Android (operating system)|Android]] and [[BlackBerry OS]] ** [http://www.appello.com/wisepilot/ WisePilot] by Appello for [[iOS]], [[Android (operating system)|Android]] and [[BlackBerry OS]]. **[[OsmAnd]] for [[Android (operating system)|Android]] smartphones<ref>{{cite web |url=https://code.google.com/p/osmand/wiki/OsmandFunctionalitySummary |title= Osmand Functionality Summary |accessdate=3 September 2014}}</ref> **GPS Navigation & Maps - Scout for [[Android (operating system)|Android]]<ref>{{cite web |url=https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.skobbler.forevermapng&hl=en |title= GPS Nav & Maps Google play link |accessdate=3 September 2014}}</ref> *Other: **[[Apple iPhone]] using [[iOS]] 6 **[[Apple iPhone]] < [[iOS]] 6 on-line or offline using various commercial [[software]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.navigadget.com/index.php/2009/06/29/iphone-gps-apps |title=iPhone GPS apps |date=29 June 2009 |publisher=Navigadget |accessdate=7 November 2010}}</ref> **[[Waze]], a free app providing turn-by-turn navigation on [[iOS]], [[Android (operating system)|Android]], [[Windows Mobile]], [[Symbian]], [[BlackBerry OS]] and [[Windows Phone]]
==References== {{reflist}}

{{Infobox University |name = University18 Business School |image=University18 Business School logo.jpg |established = 2009 |director = Raunak Singh |city = {{flagicon|India}} [[New Delhi]] |country = [[India]] |type = Online Distance Education, Executive Education |affiliations =[[Karnataka State Open University]] |website= [http://www.ubs.edu.in www.ubs.edu.in] }}
'''University18 Business School''' is a 'not for profit' Online Management Education Institution based out of India.
A collaboration between the Sampuran Prakash Foundation and [[University18]], UBS in partnership with the [[Karnataka State Open University]], India, provides accredited post graduate degree programs to working professionals and other distance learners.
Set up in 2009, UBS currently offers the following MBA Programs: * MBA for Professionals * MBA in IT * MBA in Entrepreneurship, Small Business Management and Strategy.
UBS has students from across the Indian Sub-Continent, besides America, the Middle East, United Kingdom, and Africa.
Karnataka State Open University has been de-recognized and any admission after 2012 if considered to be in-valid. The related links can be found at the end of the page.
== References & Press == * [http://www.financialexpress.com/news/karnataka-state-open-university-launches-virtual-classroom-programs/479746/ June 22, 2009 Financial Express - Karnataka State Open University launches virtual classroom programs ] * [http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/mysore/KSOU-signs-up-for-online-MBA-programme/articleshow/4689157.cms June 22, 2009 Times Of India - KSOU signs up with University18 for Online MBA Programme ] * [http://revica.europace.org/Re.ViCa%20Online%20Handbook.pdf Re.Vica - Reviewing the Virtual Campus Phenomenon - The Rise of Large Scale eLearning Initiatives Worldwide .] {{refbegin}} (The Re.ViCa Project (Agreement n°2007–2608/001–001) has been funded with support from the European Commission.){{refend}} *http://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/bangalore/KSOU-fails-to-get-UGC-recognition-yet-again/article16071791.ece *http://www.deccanherald.com/content/484424/marks-card-scam-ksou-files.html
== External links == * [http://www.ubs.edu.in University18 Business School Official Website] * [http://www.ksoumysore.com Karnataka State Open University Official Website] * [http://www.facebook.com/University18 University18 on Facebook]

revision.text:
'''Viscous damping''' [[force]] is a formulation of the [[damping]] phenomena, in which the source of damping force is modeled as a function of the [[volume]], shape, and [[velocity]] of an object traversing through a real fluid with [[viscosity]].<ref>Mechanical Vibrations, Rao, 5th ed.</ref>
Typical examples of viscous damping in mechanical systems include: * Fluid films between surfaces * Fluid flow around a piston in a cylinder * Fluid flow through an orifice * Fluid flow within a journal bearing
==See also== * [[Hysteresis]]
==References== <references />
[[Category:Mechanical vibrations]] [[Category:Fluid mechanics]] [[Category:Control theory]]

[[Image:Europarque - Sta. Maria da Feira3.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Visionarium]] '''Visionarium''' is a science museum with interactive displays in Portuguese and English covering subjects ranging from the [[History of Portugal (1415-1542)|Portuguese voyages of discoveries]] to the interiors of [[Integrated circuit|microchip]]s and [[Cell (biology)|cell]]s. It is located in [[Santa Maria da Feira Municipality|Santa Maria da Feira]], Portugal.
'''Closed since April 2018'''
It was inspired on the ''[[Cité des Sciences et de l'Industrie]]'' (France) and the [[Exploratorium]] (USA).
== Location == The ''Visionarium — Centro de Ciência do Europarque'' is an interactive museum located in [[Espargo]], Santa Maria da Feira, in its congressial perimeter Europarque, and is owned by ''[[Associação Empresarial de Portugal]]'' (Entrepreneurship Association of Portugal). Situated from only 15 minutes of [[Porto]], it explains every detail about knowledge. With six divided rooms (odissey), an auditorium, it contains more than over 25.000 m2 of green space and services.
== Awards == Visionarium as a token of its outlooks won the "European Museum of the Year Award" from the "European Museum Forum" in 2000.
== Appearances ==
=== [[Rádio e Televisão de Portugal|RTP]] === In 1999, RTP launched a 90 episodes mini-series containing its characters, with Portuguese voices. Going years into the future, and they will appear on books.
=== [[Jornal de Notícias]] === In 2006, they launched a series of 12 books containing 12 CDs, with many of the mini-series shown, containing its characters.
But not only do they make experiences multimedia, they also make experiments in the outdoors. Since its launch, there have been made countless experiments and experiences whether they are on Summer vacation or where the kids are in classes. All ages are suitable.
== Characters == There are characters describing each part that the museum has:
==="Cósmico"=== From the Universe Odyssey (a part of the museum in which it contains all the explanations of the Universe) is most described in which he appears in the books, which is only 2.
==="Bit"=== From the Information Odyssey (a part of the museum in which it explains all technological explanations, and other stuff like speaking into a virtual character from a screen and seeing yourself on front) knows all the technological explanations like binary numbers.
==="Atomium"=== From the Matter Odyssey (a part of the museum in which it explains all molecular explanations) knows everything in this part. He knows the periodic table even backwards and forwards.
==="Vita"=== From the Life Odyssey (a part of the museum in which its explained the meanings of life and even other simple stuff of the human body) knows all explainable reasons, in here.
==="Cassiopeia"=== From the Earth Odyssey (a part of the museum in which its known all of the Earth's history) knows everything in this manner.
=== "Labirinfo" === He is the center of all of Visionarium's facility, since, he's never seen in any odyssey room, or since he's always seen (in books) in which you have to make experiments in your own house.
== External links == * [http://www.visionarium.pt Official website of Visionarium] * [http://www.europarque.pt Official website of Europarque] * [http://www.aeportugal.pt Official site of AEP (Associação Empresarial de Portugal)]

[[Image:Zenrin-Asahi building.JPG|thumb|right|Zenrin head office building in [[Riverwalk Kitakyushu]]]] {{nihongo|'''Zenrin Co. Ltd.'''|株式会社ゼンリン|Kabushiki-gaisha Zenrin|{{tyo|9474}}}} is a Japanese [[map]] [[publishing company|publisher]]. Founded in 1948, the company is known as a maker of residential maps and software used in personal computers and [[Automotive navigation system]]s. It is a leading Japanese company in the production of mapping software.
==Head office== Zenrin's head office is in the Zenrin-Asahi Building at 1-1-1, Muromachi, [[Kokurakita-ku, Kitakyūshū|Kokura-Kita Ward]], [[Kitakyūshū]]. The building stands on the spot where noted [[Edo period]] mapmaker [[Ino Tadataka|Inō Tadataka]] began his mapping of [[Kyūshū]], in the midst of a modern shopping and cultural center called [[Riverwalk Kitakyushu]]. The company also has a development center (Techno Center) at Nakabaru Shinmachi 3-1, [[Tobata-ku, Kitakyūshū|Tobata Ward]], Kitakyushu.
In the U.S., Zenrin provides navigation software and expertise to [[Nissan]] North America, [[Honda]]'s [[Internavi]] in car telematics service in Japan, and other automobile and navigation systems hardware manufacturers. Zenrin is also continuing to explore collaborative efforts with other electronic and auto manufacturers. Field research crews collect data throughout the United States, Canada, Mexico, Brazil, and survey businesses along America’s Interstate's to integrate into their navigation software and databases. Businesses, organizations, and travelers nationwide utilize this data in a variety of applications and settings.
==International offices== Zenrin USA, Inc., located between San Francisco and Silicon Valley at 851 Traeger Avenue, Suite 210, San Bruno, CA, 94066 USA (650-615-4200).
Zenrin Europe GmbH, located in Münsterstr. 306, 40470 Düsseldorf, Germany (+49-211-369-780).
==President== {{nihongo|[[Zenshi Takayama]]|[[:ja:高山善司|高山善司]]||1962-}} has been the President and CEO of Zenrin Co. Ltd., since April 1, 2008. Mr. Takayama joined Zenrin Co. Ltd. in 1986 and has been its Director since 2006. He graduated from the Seinan Gakuen University.
{{nihongo|[[Shinobu Ōsako]]|[[:ja:大迫忍|大迫忍]]||1945-2005}} was president from 1980 until his retirement in 2001. Inheriting the company from his father, he built it into a major company in mapping and vehicle-mounted navigation software. He was also the first president of the [[StarFlyer]] airline.
==Map museum== A map museum is located on the on 14th floor of the company’s home office building. It is open 10:00-17:00 weekdays, closed weekends and Japanese national holidays. Admission is ¥100.
